==English==
{{wp|Mars (mythology)|mul=Mars (planet)}}
[[File:Mars symbol (fixed width).svg|thumb|Mars planetary symbol]]
[[File:Mars_23_aug_2003_hubble.jpg|right|thumb|220px|Mars (planet)]]

===Pronunciation===
* {{a|RP}} {{IPA|en|/ˈmɑːz/}}
* {{a|GA}} {{IPA|en|/ˈmɑɹz/}}
* {{rhymes|en|ɑː(ɹ)z|s=1}}
* {{audio|en|en-us-mars.ogg|Audio (US)}}

===Etymology 1===
From {{inh|en|enm|Mars}}, from {{der|en|la|Mārs||god of war}}, from older Latin (older than 75 {{BC}}) {{m|la|Māvors}}. {{m|osc|𐌌𐌀𐌌𐌄𐌓𐌔}} was his [[w:Oscan language|Oscan]] name. He was also known as ''Marmor'', ''Marmar'' and ''Maris'', the latter from the Etruscan deity [[Maris]].

==Latin==

===Etymology===
From {{der|la|itc-ola|Māvors}}, from {{inh|la|itc-pro|*Māwortis}}. ''Mamers'' was his [[w:Oscan language|Oscan]] name. He was also known as ''Marmor'', ''Marmar'' and ''Maris'', the latter from the Etruscan deity [[Maris]].

===Pronunciation===
* {{la-IPA|Mārs}}

===Proper noun===
{{la-proper noun|Mārs<3>|g=m}}

# {{senseid|la|Q111}}{{topics|la|Planets of the Solar System}}{{l|en|Mars}} (planet)
# {{senseid|la|Q112}}{{topics|la|Roman deities}}[[#English|Mars]] (Roman god)

====Usage notes====
The name of the god could, through {{m|la|interpretatio romana}}, serve to replace the name of a war god in a foreign language. Thus [[w:Saxo Grammaticus|Saxo Grammaticus]], for example, uses the term to refer to the Norse god [[Odin]], alternating it with the borrowed form {{m|la|Ōthinus}}.

====Declension====
{{la-ndecl|Mārs<3>}}

===Noun===
{{la-noun|Mārs<3.both>|g=m}}

# [[war]], [[battle]], [[conflict]]
#: {{uxi|la|{{l|la|aequatus|aequato}} '''Marte'''|made equal the battle}}

====Declension====
{{la-ndecl|Mārs<3.both>}}

====Derived terms====

|Mārcus

|mārtiaticus

|mārticultor

}}
